comments.commentBody: Another disappointing oral argument day at the Supreme Court. It was so obvious Roberts, Alito, and Scalia were biased. They want to end affirmative action because "the way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race." The clock is ticking for Roberts: no more of this nonsense; 12 years is enough, 25 is just unbearable. Alito and Scalia--both Italian-Americans, both considered ethnic minorities to this day but who by virtue of their skin color can transcend the "definitive" features of American whiteness--attempt to validate their identity by attacking a politically unpopular policy deemed unnecessary, if not sinful, by white people. And who can forget that lawyer who were it not for affirmative action would probably not be sitting on the bench today: Poor Justice Thomas; affirmative action traumatized him but sent him to Yale and ultimately the Supreme Court. Why have they shut their doors to a more balanced, intellectual, and fair legal inquiry on the subject? At least Kennedy is open to the idea of remanding the case to seek additional facts and perhaps come up with alternatives. Oh, speaking of alternatives, in Glosip v Gross, Roberts, Alito, and Scalia grilled the defense attorney for failing to name an alternative to Oklahoma's lethal injection protocol. Why didn't they pressure university lawyers to do the same. No, instead they simply attacked. The irony of things: Sotomayor got so much grief for her Latina comment.
Income inequality should be taken into consideration. All aid criteria should be both need and academically based.
I guess once Scalia secured a lifetime spot on the Supreme Court, he could be as racist as he wants to be.
Good for her.  There is a path for anyone in this country determined to succeed and putting in hard work to get it done.

I see a lot of comments accepting the idea that the University of Texas has a harder curriculum than other state schools providing the same education. Thus inferring that the other state schools are inferior. This "idea" is patently untrue! A good education is available in all state colleges, and the only value of a UT education is name recognition on a job application. I might agree with the "idea" if UT was the only school in the state providing the disciplines desired by minority students (and Ms. Fischer too), but that is not the case.
BTW, I now live in Virginia, and my granddaughter did not make the cut for a state 4 year college. She took 2 years at Northern Virginia Community College, got the required GPA, and is in a State College, George Mason University, Fairfax County. Not Virginia Tech., or UVA, but a darned good school.

And what of the bright white girl who doesn't get into college because of circumstance, lack of encouragement, support or role models, doesn't improve her lot in life, and continues down a path of poverty and despair?

Nothing for her then?

EXACTLY.

Win/win.
Dishonesty will never die; try to look at it that way.
"poor whites were a forgotten minority in this country" - not to the Klan.

I grew up poor and white in a large American city. I feel I'm liberal & open-minded on most social issues including racial inequalities, but I always felt that poor whites were a forgotten minority in this country. At least poor Blacks have their vocal spokespersons; poor white trash have nobody. I've seen a lot of white racism. However, I've seen & experienced, first-hand, black racism too, sometimes violent, which is now called "doing the right thing".

I tend to be in favor of reasonable affirmative action based on economics, which would probably disproportionately help Blacks anyway, but not based on ethnics.

Wasn't it Doctor Martin Luther King, himself, who intoned that hew looked to a time "when people will be judged NOT by the colour of their skin but by the content of their character."?

In this and these cases we are talking about the content of people's brain matter and the ability to make educated contributions in America and the World. We are talking abouit the ability to function with literacy and math skills and the general precepts about having a basic education in America. We must have knowledge and acknowledgement about our potential and our limitations and do our best within that framework. I was a "C" Student; I knew I was not going to get into Harvard. College admission should be based on grades, intellectual merit and ability to prove to the institution that you are worthy of their selection process and their academic and educational standards for the students they want on their campus. Even now for the sake of boosterism we see colleges teaching "jock" classes so that their stadiums will be filled and eventually their "student-athletes may "grace" the NFL. The process may as well be a Plantation Mentality and something akin to labour practices at the time Upton Sinclair wrote "The Jungle." This is a bald-faced way to earning an uneducated paycheck. Many of these so-called student athletes cannot utter two understandable words in a row comprising a sentence, or phrase during an interview.
Let's also abolish legacy admissions and donation-based admissions (aka buying your way in), too. One exam across the board randomly assigned with no prior preparation allowed. End of story.

It's about time we do away with the racist policy that is affirmative action.  If we want to achieve a truly colorblind society, we cannot consider race as a factor for acceptance, end of story.  There is evidence to indicate (and has been for quite some time) that minorities and their reputations are injured by affirmative action more than the opportunity presented helps.
Those born after 1970 .. simply can't go along with your argument.
Let me guess, you're white?

Those of us in Texas understand that we have a supply/demand problem. We need more top Tier 1 spots for our great students! In the mean time I agree with this analysis:

"It's true that the university, for whatever reason, offered provisional admission to some students with lower test scores and grades than Fisher. Five of those students were black or Latino. Forty-two were white.
Neither Fisher nor Blum mentioned those 42 applicants in interviews. Nor did they acknowledge the 168 black and Latino students with grades as good as or better than Fisher's who were also denied entry into the university that year. Also left unsaid is the fact that Fisher turned down a standard UT offer under which she could have gone to the university her sophomore year if she earned a 3.2 GPA at another Texas university school in her freshman year."
Freshman year at a strong, but not yet top 15 school followed by three years at a top 15 school at what at the time was a very cheap rate was a great deal. We keep saying we want our kids to be tough, resiliant, not be pliant to the trends. Ms. Fisher and her legal team have shown the opposite of these character traits.
Think some more.

Justice Scalia is right. The Texas Top Ten Percent Policy did not increase black enrollment at the University of Texas at Austin as expected because many black students whose class standing ensured them automatic admission opted instead to attend on the University of Texas System's nine regional universities. The tuition is lower at these regional universities and the flunk-out rate is much lower than at UT-Austin. They allow students to save money by living at home. These regional universities are not as prestigious as UT-Austin, but they offer quality education and their graduates get jobs.  Minority students who enroll in one of the regional universities are much less likley to wind up with no diploma but a burdensome student debt.
Probably does in those who have a predisposition to it, nh. I'm a white woman in my mid-50s and I've never seen the resentments from any other quarter.
I think that it is important to ask whether affirmative action helps fight against racism or actually worsens it by promoting stereotypes, resentment

No, the theory behind aa is that there is value to the student body in diversity. You can't learn as much from a room full of rich white guys as you can from a class that more reasonably reflects actual society.

And there is no one dimensional scale of Qualified or any reliable way to assign people to that scale if it existed..

It's a perfect example of white male privilege in action, Kevin. Those with the influence and power tend to hire, mentor and promote those who are most like themselves. It's also the reason so few women reach the top echelon of large corporations or the halls of government.

The theory behind affirmative action seems to be that the way to achieve equality is to give preferences to certain races, instead of focusing on developing equally qualified candidates.

In practice, one of the downsides of that is that anyone who is one of the privileged classes is treated with skepticism by the non-privileged majority. I see it at work, in the community, and yes, in college admissions.

What's interesting is that the policies seem from my perspective (and i may be wrong) to have created a warped system where these people are actually shepherded onto an alternate path that doesn't lead to the actual halls of power. Every company I've worked at has been fairly diverse holistically, until you look at the front office, the people getting business who were ultimately the key to the company's success. That area was usually 95% male, and white/asian. Audit, accounting, technology, back office? Diverse.

It's all very screwy and frustrating, and leads to stereotyping. Every time people see someone from one of the privileged classes, you can tell there's a certain doubt - is this guy here because he deserves it?

I don't know if it's feasible (this stuff is all very complicated and I'm just an idiot on the internet) but I'd prefer it if there was more of a focus on developing equally qualified candidates, because promoting less qualified ones is very destabilizing.

I think what you're seeing is their reaction to the pernicious destructive nature of an explicitly race based society. They've been warning against it, and now we're living it. We can now see plausible evidence that it hasn't helped over time, and in many ways has hurt us all.

The remarks of Justice Scalia and Roberts renew my feeilng that, in general, most of the people on the Court are seriously out of touch. Scalia seems to want to follow the Trump pattern of saying more and more outrageous statements to get attention, and Roberts because of his apparent lack of understanding of what America should be about. Why should there be diverse people in Science classes? Because a big part of education is to be exposed to different ideas and people and to become more confident in the world. Because it would be useful that all American citizens have a good education in science. Perhaps the Justices have been picked from such rarified backgrounds and educations that they are unable to know what is really going on out there, and future appointments should be more diverse, I.e. Maybe from a law school from someplace other than the Eastern Seaboard?  Ted Cruz and Tom Cotton seem to be a good reason to avoid Harvard for awhile. It would be interesting to see the drop out rates from UT. I would suspect that there are a good number from the automatic admits. The supposition that any student that is admitted because of any affirmative action analysis would be an automatic failure is objectionable. I have seen many people come from small high schools, with no advanced courses, go on to be very successful in college and professional school. I am very tired of the classism, snobbishness and judgmental statements, such as that of Justice Scalia.

"Scalia thinks blacks belong in "lesser" schools? "
No, he thinks students who didn't perform as well in high school would be better served by these schools.
Yeah, that's not what he said. But I am sure it will find its place in the pantheon of things Progressives just know to be true no matter what.
Scalia thinks blacks belong in "lesser" schools? Didn't Jimmy "The Greek" Snyder get canned for expressing essentially the same sentiment?
On that basis, then everyone in all colleges are African anyway, and we don't need to admit more Africans!

Even into 1960s, my grandparents lived our west in a tin-roofed shack with no electricity or running water. They had an outhouse and carried water from a well. My grandfather shot game for food and my grandmother cleaned the schoolhouse until she was in her 80s. All three of their children went to state universities, even their daughter, back at a time when few women went to college.

None of their children or grandchildren became rich, but we all understood that it was up to us to make something of our lives, so we got on with it.

The fallacy that all white people are born rich is just that.
We should first "do x, y and z to address the real problems that make AA necessary". Then, as you say, AA will no longer be necessary.
That's just seems to be the way it works these days. In a similar vein, many of the men shot by police are unsympathetic characters as well, but somehow they get media attention.
Are you saying that white and asian students in a physics class lack living social conscience that only black and hispanic students can provide?

"Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. questioned the value of diversity in at least some academic settings. “What unique perspective does a minority student bring to a physics class?” he asked."  The answer is a window into a living social conscience, too frequently absent as in the shoddy nuclear energy planning exemplified at Fukushima.

Ah, but a gifted white student from a poor family could find herself in exactly the same position as the smart black kids you mention. Perhaps the criteria for affirmative action should be social and financial rather that blatantly racial.
